this video is such a mess. it started off with this impression of an actual physics experiment (testing different types of sunscreens with different SPF's for different lengths of time) in a fun....YT friendly "DIY/crafts" direction....it then very quickly devolved into video essay style rabbit holes about debunking fashion blogs that have misinformation about specific brands, and the use of the term "chemical"....then it ended without answering the questions that were implied at the beginning of the video, which had become contorted into different questions after the whole FDA rabbit hole. these problems can be blamed on bad scripting and editing, but it's just bad directing. perfect example is all the superfluous spray paint footage. that goes into color theory, and how paint works as an artistic medium (additive vs subtractive color systems)...that's a completely different topic that i literally had to study in art school. it's a deep dive that gets pretty confusing for the artistic minded, and pretty bland for the physics minded.
i think this video should be remade. the specific questions addressed at the top of the video: how does sunscreen work, what is the differences between different SPF's, which is a more effective method: absorbing light, or reflecting light, and specific things to look out for as an average consumer (chemicals, inorganic/organic, ext). in the end, that's the themes i tried to pick out of this video, and scripting around these questions and using physics based tests (like the UV camera) to provide evidence for the answers would make for a far more cohesive video.

The reason why it's now required to be SPF 50+ is no joke, people thought the SPF was either how many minutes to wait for it to be effective or how many minutes it was effective for before having to re-apply it. So SPF 100 meant 100 minutes waiting for it to be effective or it would last 100 minutes, both of which were very wrong. This lead to a lot of people complaining about it's effectiveness (Either they'd wait so long it'd start to wear off and they'd get burned or they wait too long to re-apply it and get burned) which lead to the stereotype that it's less effective or equal to as effective. Since so many people misunderstood what SPF was, the FDA just said anything above 50 has to be marked as 50+ which helps mitigate the problem.

1) SPF values: As I understand it, if SPF 50 blocks 98% of UV rays, then SPF 100 blocks 99%, and if it existed SPF 200 would block 99.5%, and so on. So it is going to appear as if there is little difference between them. However, if your in the sun all day, 2% of UV rays get through with the SPF 50 sunscreen versus just 1% of UV rays with the 100 SPF. And over 8 hours, that could be a lot! Even when reapplying at least every two hours. A better way to think of it is by how long you can stay in the sun without reddening. The higher the SPF, the less UV rays get through, and the longer you can stay out before reddening. Remember, lighter skin reddens more easily than darker skin. Notes: No sunscreen blocks 100% of UV rays and sunscreen starts to wear off after 2 hours so reapply at least that frequently. 2) The reason for the Chemical and Physical distinctions is as you mentioned. The Chemical sunscreens are absorbed into the body, ie. all those chemicals are absorbed and the liver has to filter (collect) all those (unwanted) chemicals. The Physical sunscreens don't get absorbed but rather lay on the skin thereby forming a barrier between the UV rays and the skin, so very little (if any) of those chemicals actually get absorbed into bodies and livers don't have to filter out all of those chemicals.

I'm confused by this video. SPF is a measure of duration (indirectly). SPF 100 doesn't protect against instantaneous sun exposure much better that 50 SPF, if at all, but it can do it longer. This is pretty clear just by reading the FDA's website on SPF. If you compared 50 to 100 SPF (all else equal) over a period of 15 minutes, protection is close to identical, but over 6 hours the 100 SPF outperforms because it can absorb more total solar energy. This seems logical, as the sun only produces so much energy - once you cross the threshold of how much energy is incoming, you can't get much better protection. That said, the protection/duration is not doubled, as the value is exponential. Typical SPF tests last 4, 6, or 8 hours, and measure how much UVB is not blocked. QyetOne summarized this below, but here it is again.
SPF 4 = 1/4 or 25% of the radiation is not blocked (absorbed/reflected)
SPF 8 = 1/8 or 12.5%
SPF 15 = 1/15 or 6.7%
SPF 30 = 1/30 or 3.3%
SPF 50 = 1/50 or 2%
SPF 100 = 1/100 or 1%
SPF 150 = 1/150 or 0.67%
So the incremental benefit of higher and higher SPFs decreases. Of course, once you get above 50 or so, correct use and personal characteristics are probably more important than the SPF (coverage, reapplication time, skin type, sun intensity, etc.) for most people.

Also, FDA is the Food and Drug Administration, not the Federal Drug Administration.

Assuming the numbers are correct, SPF100 should let you stay twice as long in the sun for a given skin UV exposure. It is a 1/x relationship, though, so the difference between SPF10 and 20 (the latter gives you twice the sun time of the former) does not have the same effect as between SPF90 and 100 (the latter gives you 11% more sun time than the former).

There does come a point where the safe sun exposure time exceeds the expected physical lifetime of the layer of sunscreen (through sweating, abrasion, etc) at which point a higher SPF is loses any meaningful purpose.

There is also the issue of whether other wavelengths, not blocked by the sunscreen, also cause skin problems.

The distinction between "chemical" and "physical" sunscreen is not due to whether sunscreen is made from chemicals, but rather the action of how the ingredient screens you from the sun. "Chemical" ones are so called because the protect you from UV rays via a chemical reaction - absorbing and then converting UV rays into heat - and "physical" ones are called that because they physically reflect or block the UV rays from your skin. This isn't that hard to grasp especially with the wealth of information out there regarding sunscreen ingredients and how they work; it is not merely a marketing tactic.

"Chemical" sunscreens get a bad rep because of the way the work - the conversion of UV rays into heat can cause skin sensitivity in some people, which is why "physical" sunscreens are touted as a "better" alternative to the "chemical" ones. Also, as you mentioned in your video, certain sunscreen ingredients can cause coral bleaching, and further studies have to be done on whether sunscreen can actually be absorbed into our bloodstream, and further, cause damage to or affect our bodies. Yes, it is true that lumping all chemical sunscreens together as "bad" is unnecessary but the way you explained why they are considered bad shows that you did not do enough research to educate people about the very sunscreens that you're advocating. Also the fact that you didn't explain how sunscreens are rated the way they are rated, one of the most basic and important factors to consider when purchasing sunscreen, shows you did not do enough research, or at least didn't think it was worth educating your audience about.

Speaking of how sunscreens are rated, you mentioned chemical sunscreens should be further classified into ones that work for UVA and UVB rays, yet you did not mention SPF is only the factor rating for effectiveness against UVB rays while PA is the factor rating for effectiveness against UVA rays.

I have always heard the two sunscreen categories described as "chemical" and "mineral." I don't think the chemical bit is an intent at scaring people. It's just descriptive of how the sunscreen works. When in the video they say that these types of sunscreens "absorb" the UV light, what they really mean is that the UV light induces a chemical reaction within those chemicals, where they are broken down into smaller molecules. By giving energy to the chemical reaction, the light becomes less dangerous, and its frequency shifts down so that it is mostly heat rather than penetrating rays. And this is why they say you have to reapply the sunscreen every few hours: the chemicals get consumed as they work. They also get consumed if the sunscreen in left in a hot location, so it's best to not leave your tube of sunscreen out in the sun when you're at the beach. The mineral sunscreen, on the other hand, are physical barriers that are placed between the light and the skin. No chemical reaction takes place (or only a tiny one). The light simply bounces off it. This is also why you can generally see mineral sunscreens on people's skin. It's an actual physical barrier. But they also make tinted varieties that are less noticable.

Both chemical and mineral sunscreen contain chemicals that are potentially toxic to some degree. The chemical sunscreens we use in the US are banned in Europe and vice versa. (But this might also just be protectionism because the chemicals in European sunscreens are produced by European companies, and the US sunscreens' are made by US companies). However, the molecules in mineral sunscreens are orders of magnitude larger than those in chemical sunscreens, and the latter get broken down into even smaller ones. So the chemicals in chemical sunscreens are much more likely to make it into your bloodstream than those from mineral sunscreens.

Regarding effectiveness, my understanding is that the chemical ones tend to work somewhat better, although they need to be continuously reapplied because the UV light is constantly breaking them down. With mineral sunscreens you also have to make sure that they have BOTH zinc oxide and titanium dioxide in them, as the two minerals are effective against different light wavelengths. My personal sunscreen strategy is to use a mineral sunscreen as my every day walking about sunscreen. I mix an untinted and tinted so that it matches my skin color. If I'll have a long sun exposure, then I have a sunscreen that is primarily mineral but also contains some of the chemicals. To me that seems the best tradeoff between safety from the sunscreen vs safety from the sun.

I understand that the chemical vs physical distinction has been used to advocate for BS claims of “natural is better,” but many chemical (organic) sunscreens in the US are actually not the best for sun protection. Many are not broad spectrum, cause damage to coral reefs, are not photostable (ie they break down when exposed to light), can cause skin sensitivity, and can possibly cause hormonal disruption. Many of these negatives are primarily due to the way organic sunscreens work by— by absorbed into the skin and converting uv light to heat through their chemical bonds. Inorganic sunscreens on the other hand reflect uv light while sitting on top of your skin, and (unless nanotized) cannot be absorbed into your skin

You can block UV light either by absorbing it or reflecting it. However, because UV reflecting material reflects visible light as well, it will be recognized by our eyes and as a result it doesn't look good, while UV absorbing material can selectively absorb UV light. By the way, inorganic titanium dioxide and zinc oxide are also basically UV absorbing material, those are famous semiconductors that have band gap energy of ~3.0 eV (= ~400 nm light), which means that there activation just start from UV light while not absorbing visible light!

You can protect something from the light by use of a black paper or aluminum foil. First is black because absorbs almost all light and reflects almost none, the latter is shining because reflects almost everything and absorbs the tiny rest.  The net effect is the same - the something is protected from the light.

FPS 4 means you may get 4x more exposure to get the same damage than without it. That means it allows only 25% of the total UV light to pass through (1 / 0.25 = 4). Conversely, it blocks 75% of the UV light.
Now, FPS 10 means 10% goes through and it blocks 90%.
FPS 30 lets only 3.333% through, blocking 96,67%.
When you increase to FPS 50, you're now blocking 98%. That's only 1.33 percentage points more blockage in absolute values. So there's really not much of a difference.

5:02 SPF is intuitive (a simple multiplication factor of time), but the mention of "diminishing returns" reminded me that it's easier to compare larger numbers by translating them to dBi attenuation (SPF 10: 10dBi; SPF 20: 13dBi; SPF 50: 17dBi; SPF 100: 20dBi). SPF 20 is twice as effective as SPF 10; Likewise, SPF 100 is twice as effective as SPF 50. But while the difference in SPF rating is only 10 in the first case and 50 in the second, in terms of dBi the difference is only 3 in both cases (10 ⟶ 13, and 17 ⟶ 20). So SPF is useful in absolute terms, but in relative terms dBi is a better way to compare two products.

Sunscreen has some pretty cool science - it's a shame Paul Doherty isn't around to enlighten us all...  for the 50+ vs. 100+ SPF, once you think about what it means, the difference should seem negligible in most cases.  SPF 50 should provide 50 times your skin's natural protection against the sun, so that 50 minutes wearing it is equivalent to 1 minute unprotected. So, in theory, four hours wearing 50+ SPF in direct sun would be equivalent to about 5 minutes unprotected.  Four hours with 100 SPF, would be equivalent to 2.5 unprotected, which doesn't seem drastically different from 5 minutes.  As the effectiveness drops over time following application, it would seem that how long the sunscreen lasts would have bigger effect than SPF rating in this case.

The reason the SPF makes little perceptual difference when looking at sunscreen in a UV camera yet still made a measurable difference in the research has to do with the cumulative effects of doubling the blockage of UV light. With each doubling of SPF, half of the previous level of UV light gets through. When we start halving the amount of light (SPF 2), that makes a big perceptual difference because there was a lot of light to begin with. The next increase, to SPF 4, means half of the UV light at SPF 2. A third doubling, to SPF 8, preserves just one quarter of the UV light compared to SPF 2. But this time the drop in the amount of light was nominally much less. Look how little nominal UV levels drop at higher SPF levels as we increase SPF all the way to 100:

SPF 1 --> No sunscreen, so 100 units of light show up in UV camera and get through to cause tanning and damage to DNA.
SPF 2 --> Drop of 50 units of UV light. Now just 50 show up in the UV camera and cause tanning and DNA damage.
SPF 4 --> Drop of 25 units of UV light
SPF 8 --> Drop of 12 units of UV light
SPF 16 --> Drop of 6 units of UV light
SPF 32 --> Drop of 3 units of UV light
SPF 64 --> Drop of just 1 unit of UV light
SPF 100--> Drop of just 1 unit of UV light. But that's still only about half of the damaging UV light at SPF 64!

To our not-so-sensitive eyes (and the not-so-sensitive UV camera), a drop of 1 unit of light is imperceptible. But to our sensitive skin cells, it's not. That's why the research still showed that stronger SPF sunscreen does make a difference.

"SPF" is defined by a testing method, where the SPF number is the threshold of how much UVA/UVB doesn't make it through the product (applied in a standardized layer). It's a very simple bit of math!
SPF 4 = 1/4 or 25% of the radiation is not blocked (absorbed/reflected)
SPF 8 = 1/8 or 12.5%
SPF 15 = 1/15 or 6.7%
SPF 30 = 1/30 or 3.3%
SPF 50 = 1/50 or 2%
SPF 100 = 1/100 or 1%
SPF 150 = 1/150 or 0.67%
So it makes good sense that you can't readily tell the difference at higher SPF's because the difference is getting tinier and tinier. The difference between SPF 15 and 30 is 3.4% radiation getting through, but the difference between 50 and 150 is only 1.3%. This is also interesting in terms of evaluating the UV camera's receptivity, because SPF doesn't discriminate between how it gets results (absorbing vs reflecting), but the camera is registering the UV radiation emitted/reflected, so as you observed absorption darkens and reflection may be invisible or actually lighter. So if you had two different brands achieving the same SPF value by different combinations of the two mechanisms, they may appear different on the camera even though they have the same efficacy from the skin's point of view.

The way that SPF is calculated is it supposedly tells you how many UV rays are blocked for every ray that passes through.
So SPF 15 blocks 93% of UV rays, or 1 - (1 / 15).
SPF 30 blocks 96.7% of UV rays, or 1 - (1 / 30).
A label showing SPF 60 seems like it would be twice as effective as SPF 30, but it only blocks 98.3%, making it only 1.7% better.
By the time you get to SPF 50, the difference between SPF 50 and 90 is less than 1%.
So even though it's amazing marketing power to say "SPF 80", it is misleading, and that's why you have to say SPF 50+.

I usually never see this explained, but the SPF number is related to what percentage of the UV they let through. They let through 1/(SPF#)% of UV.  So SPF25 lets through 4%, SPF50 lets through 2%, and SPF100 lets through 1%. So SPF25/50/100 block-reflect 96%/98%/99% of UV. Which makes sense why there is very little difference between SPF30+ under the the UV camera. Depending how you look at it; SPF50 could be twice as effective as SPF25 (letting through 2% rather than 4%) or not (blocking 98% rather than 96%).

Though a UV camera is great for visual demonstration, we shouldn't use it as a way to "do science" since visual data is usually imprecise and subjective. Instead, such a camera is likely made from UV photodiodes, whose level can be quantitatively measured. You also shouldn't be measuring sunscreen effectiveness by how much UV light it reflects or absorbs, but rather how much it doesn't reflect or absorb. Instead of looking at the sunscreen from the same side as the UV source, you should look at it from the other side, in a low UV control space. For example, take a room with only one window, and measure the UV levels in the room behind the window. Then put a single type of sunscreen on the entire window and make the same measurement. Clean the window thoroughly and test multiple sunscreens. This should give you an idea of how much UV light is passing through the sunscreen. As a better test, if you had access to a sheet of material that had similar absorptive properties as human skin, and low UV blocking levels, you could place that over the window and apply the sunscreen to that material.

I'm rather shocked that the true meaning of SPF is not discussed. SPF is the hour exposure equivalent. So 30 SPF allows you to be exposed for 30 hours, while receiving the exposure of 1 unprotected hour. Understanding this, there are a variety of questions that come into play. 1. What is your body's ability to handle and repair exposure damage. 2) Can higher levels of exposure be beneficial? For 1, there is a threshold of repair and replacement that the body can handle with no adverse effects. For 2, they answer is yes. People living in Denver which have higher background radiation levels actually have lower cancer risk because the cellular repair mechanisms are more activated. To be in a zero-exposure environment would lead to the shutdown of the mechanisms and mutations would become prolific. So, my own reasoning is this: Use a SPF which is rated for how may hours I can handle before burning. I estimate 1 hour, (less in spring and more going into fall). So if I will be out for 8 hours, I use SPF 8. I get no more damage than by body can handle, and I develop a tan (natural protection) which is usable even when not wearing sun screen.

I think a lot of the controversy comes from people not understanding what SPF means. I've been pitched sunscreens that don't cause cancer, and I believe them on a compositional basis. However the USE of that same sunscreen may. There is actual statistically significant* (*formal definition) evidence that people who use sunscreen have HIGHER risk even though they don't burn. My take on it is this: think about it this way: if you use sunscreen as a block, you never let your body develop it's own protection. Any time you are not wearing sunscreen you're in a more vulnerable state, letting those photons damage DNA. However if you use sunscreen to develop your tan, providing natural protection, you expose your self to less "chemicals" and reduce your need for such chemicals.

Finally, do wear "appropriate" sunscreen but always make sure your glasses and sunglasses are UV rated. UV accelerates cataract development, and while we have cataract surgery, nothing is as good as your natural lens!

As a chemist, what I can say is that inorganic UV filters must be in the form of nanoparticles in order to refract UV light. But the size of nanoparticles is very important because although smaller nanoparticles diffract UV light better, they can be absorbed by the skin more easily and at the moment there's not enough studies on the effects of absorbed nanoparticles such as zinc oxide or titanium dioxide. Moreover, nanoparticles of titanium dioxide are known to catalyse, as a result of UV radiation, the production of peroxides and radical species in aqueous environments that can be very harmful to cells. With this in mind, the size of nanoparticles must be established and regulated by law very accurately.
As far as organic filters are concerned, most molecules contained in sun creams are based on natural compounds with known UV light absorption activity. That's why many creams have a slight carrot aroma for example.

I guess I don't understand why the standard "more research needs to be done" statement at the end of the paper demonstrating significant stronger protection of inorganic SPF 100 vs SPF 50 was pounced upon as super important and emphasized more than the actual findings. It's not about your opinions of "diminishing returns". Replicate the experiment, conduct your own study, or identify some flaw in the study to show otherwise. Try to keep things as scientific as possible before digressing into feelings. Scientific papers commonly end by saying that more research needs to be done; it's the nature of the continuum of scientific discovery.

This is the main finding of the 2018 article you mentioned:
"Following an average 6.1 ± 1.3 hours of sun exposure, investigator-blinded evaluation identified 55.3% of the participants (110 of 199) as more sunburned on the SPF 50+ protected side and 5% (10 of 199) on the SPF 100+ protected side. After exposure, 40.7% of the participants (81 of 199) exhibited increased erythema scores (by ≥1) on the SPF 50+ protected side as compared with 13.6% (27 of 199) on the SPF 100+ protected side" (Williams et al., 2018).

The reasons for choosing "physical" over "chemical" sunscreens extend beyond fears of toxicity (and it probably would have been better to have cleared that up and maybe even referenced your own citation (Hayden et al., 2005) as a positive sign instead leaving doubt lingering in the air before inexplicably concluding that at the end of the day we should wear sunscreen). People need to know if the pros outweigh the cons and the nature of the cons besides rumored concerns. Chemical (organic) sunscreens convert UV light to heat which comes with a host of issues that are related to skin temperature (darkening/melasma, increased flushing of skin for those with rosacea-prone skin). Additionally, there is a lag in efficacy for organic sunscreens and problems for people with acne-prone skin.

This was a cool-looking video courtesy of a UV camera but a bit disappointing on scientific end since I feel that it didn't really answer any questions or create a clear path for further inquiry. It also did not explain some of the key points of contention that could at least lead the view to read further into issues beyond "debates" of unclear origin.

If not destroyed it can cover very large areas very fast. What’s worse is that its juice causes severe burns. That’s common knowledge in Russia. A much less known fact is that those burns are not caused by juice itself. These are actually sunburns. The plant’s juice causes chemical reaction which dramatically increases skin’s photosensitivity. So it’s basically a reverse sunscreen. And those severe (sometimes even lethal) burns can be avoided just by covering from sunlight.

You didn't mention what's the meaning in the SPF value.
With an SPF 50 on your skin you can stay in the sun for 50 minutes and you get the same results of 1 minute of exposure without it.
So, if you go to the beach for, say, 4 hours (240 minutes) with an SPF 50, you get the same suntan/damage of staying in the sun for 4.8 minutes without it.
If you put on an SPF 100 you get the same results of staying in the sun for 2.4 minutes without it.
That's why SPFs above 50 don't make much sense in a practical way.

RE: Chemical vs. Physical - All chemistry is just quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics anyway, so it'a ALL physics.

I was lucky enough to have taken a few in-house physics courses personally taught by Richard Feynman when I worked at Hughes Aircraft. Here's what he had to say about this in the Feynman Lectures on Physics:

"The science which is perhaps the most deeply affected by physics is chemistry. Historically, the early days of chemistry dealt almost entirely with what we now call inorganic chemistry, the chemistry of substances which are not associated with living things. Considerable analysis was required to discover the existence of the many elements and their relationships—how they make the various relatively simple compounds found in rocks, earth, etc. This early chemistry was very important for physics. The interaction between the two sciences was very great because the theory of atoms was substantiated to a large extent by experiments in chemistry. The theory of chemistry, i.e., of the reactions themselves, was summarized to a large extent in the periodic chart of Mendeleev, which brings out many strange relationships among the various elements, and it was the collection of rules as to which substance is combined with which, and how, that constituted inorganic chemistry. All these rules were ultimately explained in principle by quantum mechanics, so that theoretical chemistry is in fact physics. On the other hand, it must be emphasized that this explanation is in principle. We have already discussed the difference between knowing the rules of the game of chess, and being able to play. So it is that we may know the rules, but we cannot play very well. It turns out to be very difficult to predict precisely what will happen in a given chemical reaction; nevertheless, the deepest part of theoretical chemistry must end up in quantum mechanics."

"There is also a branch of physics and chemistry which was developed by both sciences together, and which is extremely important. This is the method of statistics applied in a situation in which there are mechanical laws, which is aptly called statistical mechanics. In any chemical situation a large number of atoms are involved, and we have seen that the atoms are all jiggling around in a very random and complicated way. If we could analyze each collision, and be able to follow in detail the motion of each molecule, we might hope to figure out what would happen, but the many numbers needed to keep track of all these molecules exceeds so enormously the capacity of any computer, and certainly the capacity of the mind, that it was important to develop a method for dealing with such complicated situations. Statistical mechanics, then, is the science of the phenomena of heat, or thermodynamics. Inorganic chemistry is, as a science, now reduced essentially to what are called physical chemistry and quantum chemistry; physical chemistry to study the rates at which reactions occur and what is happening in detail (How do the molecules hit? Which pieces fly off first?, etc.), and quantum chemistry to help us understand what happens in terms of the physical laws."

"The other branch of chemistry is organic chemistry, the chemistry of the substances which are associated with living things. For a time it was believed that the substances which are associated with living things were so marvelous that they could not be made by hand, from inorganic materials. This is not at all true—they are just the same as the substances made in inorganic chemistry, but more complicated arrangements of atoms are involved. Organic chemistry obviously has a very close relationship to the biology which supplies its substances, and to industry, and furthermore, much physical chemistry and quantum mechanics can be applied to organic as well as to inorganic compounds. However, the main problems of organic chemistry are not in these aspects, but rather in the analysis and synthesis of the substances which are formed in biological systems, in living things. This leads imperceptibly, in steps, toward biochemistry, and then into biology itself, or molecular biology."

It isnt mentioned in the video but the number of the spf means the times you need to get sunburn.
SPF 15 means that with that coating you will get sunburnt in X(t)*15, so if you're very pale and get sunburnt after 1 minute, using a SPF 15 means you'll get sunburnt in 15 minutes of exposure.
Other examples: if you get sunburn after 10 minutes, a spf 30 makes your skin get sunburnt after 300 minutes.
Keep in mind that the spf must be reapplied after some time and it needs to be applied properly (aka not too thin).

If sunscreens absorb UV it means they make your skin heat up in the sun more than it would otherwise. Perhaps it would be better if they were reflective. But is that really possible? My understanding is it's easy to find materials with a precise absorption spectrum because it's about electron energy levels. Reflection is about scattering which is relatively broad spectrum depending only on the micro-structure. Red paint doesn't selectively reflect red. It reflects white and absorbs green and blue, and these effects combine a few manometers into the surface to give the impression of reflecting red. We're used to surfaces that appear to have a precise reflection spectrum in this way. But if you're interested in the energy that passes through the options seem to be precisely selective absorption (and conversion to heat) or broad spectrum reflection. The myth that SPF 100 (99% blocking) is not significantly better than SPF 50 (98% blocking) is based on a single popularized report that failed to interpret the math correctly.

Nominally, 99% may only be 1% different from 98%, but it is indeed twice the amount of blocking, passing 1% of the total UV instead of 2%. I spent a lot of time digging into this and got right to the bottom. It's a myth, and it spread rapidly.

If you develop a sunscreen that passes only 0.5% of total UV, it would be called SPF 200, and it would be twice as effective as SPF 100.

I don't understand this idea that higher SPF sunscreen offers "diminishing returns". It's often explained like "well, SPF45 blocks 98% of UV, while SPF100 blocks 99%, so that's only 1% more" but that's totally ridiculous. What matters is the dose of UV received, so the difference between 2% and 1% is twice as much UV. Doubling the SPF factor (assuming the sunscreen works perfectly..) does indeed cut your relative dose in half. No one would dare make a similar arithmetic argument regarding regular sunglasses, glacier glasses, or eclipse viewing glasses; there's a reason those glasses they sell for eclipse viewing block 99.9999% instead of 99.9%.

As someone who spends a lot of time in very high UV environments (high altitude, clear sky, lots of snow), I understand that all sunscreens are limited in their effectiveness since it's easy to miss spots, not re-apply frequently enough, or have them degraded by abrasion, water, etc. A simple shirt offers SPF of supposedly "only" 15, yet I can spend all day out in extreme UV and not burn or even tan under a single layer of clothing, whereas even SPF50+ will have a tough time protecting my skin 100% in the same environment. So for that reason, I can understand why the FDA doesn't wan't people to just buy a ridiculously high SPF sunscreen and think it makes them invincible.

But in my experience the higher SPF sunscreens really do make a difference especially in when there is lots of snow around.

"Looks like metallic black paint" - well, "black" means that there is less scattering (aka diffuse reflection), and "metallic" means that there is more specular (mirror-like) reflection.

Let's put it like this: Imagine a photon (let's call it Bob) hitting a surface. One of several things will happen:
a) Bob gets reflected in the same angle he came. That's (specular) reflection. Think "mirror".
b) Bob gets reflected in a random angle. That's diffuse reflection or scattering. Think "matte white surface".
c) Bob passes through without being scattered, following the law of refraction. This is called transparency. Think "glass".
d) Bob passes through in a random direction. this is called translucency. Think "translucent screen".
e) Bob is absorbed and lives on as heat (which is ultimately radiated away), This is called absorption. Think "matte black surface".
e') Bob is absorbed and lives on as some other kind of energy, (maybe chemical), This is also called absorption. Think "leaf".

So, a surface appearing "like metallic black paint" on the uv camera is reflecting (a) more and diffusing (b) less uv photons. As earthlings aren't capable of photosynthesis, I think most radiation absorbed by the sunscreen will transform into heat (e), so it would be interesting to visualize the IR radiation as well, in order to estimate the amount passing through (c and d).

P.S.: When I say "One of several things will happen" I deliberately ignore the possibility of quantum superposition of several things happening simultaneously to Bob. I understand you Earthlings have some trouble wrapping your heads around quantum mechanics because they do not match with your binary logic, your concept of causality and your obsession with "things".

It's actually a lot more complicated than wearing or not wearing sunscreen - There's pros AND cons, and not just from the chemicals contained within sunscreens. It depends hugely on which time of the day you choose to go out in the sunshine and for how long, and where in the world you live. Also, let's talk about Vitamin D deficiency. Guess what the best way of getting Vitamin D is? The sun. Most people do not get adequate Vitamin D from their diets. Much of the population of Europe, for example, is completely Vitamin D deficient for much of the year, because it is impossible to obtain enough from the sun and they don't eat enough foods containing the right amounts of Vitamin D usable by the body. Not all Vitamin D supplements are equal. And lets remember that this vitamin, which acts more like a hormone than a vitamin, has numerous, protective, health benefits. https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/causes-prevention/risk/diet/vitamin-d-fact-sheet
